I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 
additional  financing  loan  to  India  for  the  Bihar  State  Highways  II  Project.  The  report  also 
describes  proposed  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  preparing  the  Road  Master  Plan  for  Bihar’s 
State Highway Development, and if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the 
authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA.1 
 
The  additional financing will  expand  the  original project  by rehabilitating and  upgrading 
2. 
254  kilometers  (km)  of  state  highways  in  Bihar  identified  under  the  Bihar  State  Highways 
Development  Program,  2007–2012.  These  severely  deteriorated  highway  sections  are  in  the 
very  poor  northern  and  southern  parts  of  the  state.  The  project  will  upgrade  existing  roads  to 
two  lanes,  strengthen  existing  pavement,  strengthen  culverts  and  bridges,  and  construct  new 
bridges  and  cross-draining  structures.  Consulting  services  will  be  provided  to  supervise  the 
implementation of civil works. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Rationale 

Bihar is one of the poorest and most economically backward states in India, with income 
3. 
per capita at less than 30% of the national average and 43% of the population living below the 
poverty  line,  well  above  the  35%  national  average.  The  state’s  population  grew  by  25%  from 
2001 to 2011. Nearly 58% of Biharis are below the age of 25, ranking highest in India. Bihar’s 
state highway network has 3,989 km of roads.2 Road density in Bihar is only 901 km per million 
people,  as  compared  to  the  national  average  of  2,567  km.  The  road  network  in  Bihar  is  very 
poor  in  terms  of  coverage  and  condition,  while  demand  for  road  transport  continuously 
increases,  as  evidenced  by  the  large  increase  in  the  state’s  population.  The  Government  of 
Bihar has scaled up investment in road development since 2007 to provide statewide access by 
successfully  rehabilitating  2,470  km  of  state  highway  with  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB) 
assistance and state resources. 
 
ADB’s Bihar State Highways Project was approved in September 2008 for $420 million.3 
4. 
The  first  project  financed  the  rehabilitation  of  820 km  of  state  highways  and  successfully 
implemented  significant  sector  reforms,  including  the  establishment  of  the  Bihar  State  Road 
Development  Corporation  (BSRDC)  and  its  adoption  of  international  best  practices  for  road 
planning  and  maintenance  systems,  financial  management,  and  public  procurement.  The  first 
project was performing well and closed in July 2012, as scheduled.  
 
5. 
The  Bihar  State  Highways  II  Project,  approved  in  September  2010  for  $300  million, 
finances  the  rehabilitation  of  356  km  of  state  highways  and  is  expected  to  be  completed  in 
2015.4   Further,  procurement for  another  33 km of  state  highway  is  being  carried  out to  utilize 
the  loan surplus.  Support  toward  adopting  best  practices  for  public–private  partnership  (PPP), 
road safety, and road asset management have been successfully implemented.5

 To further  expand  development  impact,  the  Government  of India  has requested  a  third 
6. 
loan to finance the rehabilitation of 254 km of roads in Bihar. The proposed roads for additional 
financing  were  selected  in  line  with  the  Bihar  State  Highways  Development  Program,  which 
aims to upgrade all state highways to two lanes, satisfying basic needs of rural connectivity with 
open access to all road users. The roads will be reconstructed taking road safety and flood risk 
into consideration. A survey carried out regarding the roads under the first project revealed that 
road improvement has benefited local communities including women through improved access 
to  markets,  education,  health  care,  and  other  social  services.6 Similar  benefits  are  expected 
from the proposed additional financing. 
 
The  original  project  is  performing  well.7 Implementation  progress  has  been  satisfactory 
7. 
with  the  awarding  of  all  four  civil  works  contracts,  two  supervision  consultant  contracts,  and 
capacity development TA consultant contracts, and with $40 million disbursed. The project is on 
track for completion by 2015, has experienced no construction cost overrun so far, and complies 
satisfactorily  with safeguard policy requirements. 
 
Additional  financing  will  scale  up  the  original  project  by  expanding  the  highway 
8. 
upgrading component. It will help achieve the full extent of improvements envisaged under the 
project by covering additional geographic areas in northern and southern Bihar, increasing the 
number  of  project  beneficiaries  in  poor  villages,  and  optimizing  access  to  the  state  highway 
network. It will support the state government’s priority of implementing improvements quickly to 
ensure that the development impact of the state highway network is optimized and its  benefits 
are reaped in a timely way. All necessary due diligence has been conducted. The project meets 
ADB’s eligibility criteria for additional financing as it (i) remains technically feasible, economically 
viable,  and financially  sound;  (ii)  is  accorded  high  priority  by the government;  (iii)  is consistent 
with  the  project’s  development  objectives;  and  (iv)  is  consistent  with  the  current  country 
partnership strategy.  
 
In  keeping  with  the  original  project,  the  targeted  outcome  of  the  additional  financing  is 
9. 
consistent  with  the  strategic  objectives  set  out  in  ADB's  country  partnership  strategy,  2009–
2012: (i) improve the transport system in India with a focus on poorer states, (ii) make growth 
more  inclusive,  and  (iii)  quicken  the  pace  of  poverty  reduction  and  social  development. 8   The 
additional financing is included in the India country operations business plan, 2011–2013.9  
 
10. 
The  project  will  add  value  through  four  aspects.  First,  the  project  will  address  the 
challenges of climate change—specifically the risk of flooding and increased carbon emissions 
caused  by  additional  traffic  generated  by  road  improvement—through  (i)  more  stringent 
engineering design and green landscaping; (ii) planting 10 trees for every tree removed, more 
than triple the 1:3 statutory requirement, and implementing the compensatory plantation of trees 
with strong community participation, including women, to achieve higher  rates of plant survival 
and to promote ownership; and (iii) using solar panels at construction sites to sequester carbon 
and reduce carbon emissions. Second, the project will address road safety through community 
participation by incorporating a training-of-trainers model in which men and women from project 
areas  receive  training  from  road  safety  experts  and  provide  training  in  turn  to  project-affected

communities (including to schools in project-affected areas) to sustain community engagement 
on road safety issues. Third, the project will promote gender mainstreaming by actively involving 
women 
livelihood  restoration  activities,  and  awareness 
programs. Lastly, the project will prepare a 20-year strategic master plan for developing Bihar’s 
state highways, including long-term vision and goals, an action program, and a monitoring and 
evaluation  system  with performance  indicators and targets. The  master  plan  will  be  supported 
by a financing plan for the action program, which will identify potential funding sources from the 
state government, PPP, and development partners. 
 
B. 

Impact and Outcome 

11. 
The  impact  will  be  a  more  efficient  state  road  transport  system  supporting  sustainable 
economic  growth  in  Bihar.  The  outcome  will  be  improved  transport  efficiency  and  safety  on 
project roads. 
 
C. 

Outputs 

12. 
The  outputs  will  be  (i)  building  and  upgrading  254  km  of  state  highways  (Table  1), 
(ii) improved  institutional  capacity  for  sustainable  transport  sector  development,  and  (iii) better 
road safety and greater awareness of potential social issues. The revised performance indicator 
of  the  highway  upgrading  component  is  643  km,  comprising  the  original  project’s  389 km  and 
the 254 km under the additional financing. The project will provide consulting services to support 
the implementation and monitoring of the civil works.

Investment and Financing Plans  

 
D. 
 
13. 
The  project  is  estimated  to  cost  $799  million  with  additional  financing  (Table  2).  The 
government has requested a loan of $300 million from ADB’s ordinary capital resources for the 
additional  financing  to  help finance  the  project.  The  loan  will  have  a  25-year  term,  including  a 
grace period of 5 years, straight line repayment method, an annual interest rate determined in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  London  interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based  lending  facility, 10  a 
commitment charge of 0.15% per year, and such other terms and conditions set forth in the draft 
loan  and  project  agreements.  The  government  has  provided  ADB  with  (i)  the  reasons  for  its 
decision  to borrow  under  ADB’s  LIBOR-based  lending facility  on  the  basis  of these terms  and 
conditions, and (ii) an undertaking that these choices were its own independent decision and not 
made in reliance on any communication or advice from ADB.

III. 

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 

As the Bihar State Highways Development Program will end in 2012, policy and advisory 
16. 
TA in the amount of $1 million equivalent will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical 
Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-other  sources).  The  TA  will  support  the  state  government’s 
sector  development  initiatives,  especially  for  preparing  of  a  20-year  strategic  master  plan  for 
developing  Bihar’s  state  highways,  including  long-term  vision  and  goals,  an  action  program,  a 
financing plan, and a monitoring and evaluation system with performance indicators and targets.  
 
17. 
The  TA  will  require  61  person-months  of  consulting  services,  33  international  and  28 
national experts. ADB will engage a consulting firm in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use 
of  Consultants (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  Consultants  will  be  asked  to  submit  full 
technical proposals, and quality- and cost-based selection will be used with a quality–cost ratio 
of 80:20. The terms of reference for the TA are set out in the project administration manual.  
 

IV. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

A. 

Technical 

18. 
Engineering. The engineering design was developed based on site conditions, surveys, 
and  field  investigations,  optimizing  the  required  improvement  works  for  economy  and 
construction  efficiency  in  accordance  with  Indian  standards, 12  which  align  with  applicable 

                                                
12 The  design  standard  is  based  on  Ministry  of  Road  Transport  and  Highways:  Specifications  for  Road  and  Bridge 

Works (4th Revision), published by Indian Roads Congress, 2001. 

5 

 

 6 

 

international design standards. The design was prepared to minimize land acquisition and social 
and  environmental  impacts.  A  road  safety  audit  produced  recommendations  that  were 
incorporated in the design of the project.13  
 
Operation  and  maintenance.  The  state  government  has  increased  the  maintenance 
19. 
budget from $48 million in 2006 to $79 million in 2011, an increase of 65% in 5 years that now 
substantially  meets  the  maintenance  requirements.  The  budget  achieved  100%  utilization  in 
2009–2010, compared with 90% or less in previous years, indicating that overall use efficiency 
has improved. A road maintenance policy, which includes an operate–maintain–transfer scheme 
with private sector participation, has been formulated and is awaiting cabinet approval. This will 
also contribute to funding maintenance for the rest of the state highways.  
 
B. 

Economic 

20. 
An  economic  analysis  has  been  undertaken  for  each  of  the  four  project  roads  by 
comparing options with the project and without it. The Highway Development and Management 
Model 4 was used to assess the project's economic viability. Benefits considered in the analysis 
include  time  and  vehicle  operating  cost  savings  enabled  by  the  project.  Economic  analysis 
found the project economically viable with an overall economic internal rate of return (EIRR) of 
19.5%.  Individual  road  sections  included  in  the  project  have  EIRRs  ranging  from  14.1%  to 
23.1%.  Sensitivity  analysis  confirms  the robustness of  economic  viability,  as  reducing  benefits 
by 10% and increasing costs by 10% leave the EIRR at 16.6%. The project is justified in social 
cost–benefit terms.14  
 
C. 

Governance 

21. 
Institutional  and  financial  management  capacity.  The  BSRDC  has  satisfactory 
capacity  for  project  financial  accounting  and  sufficient  knowledge  of  ADB’s  disbursement 
procedures.15 It  will  maintain  separate  records  and  accounts  to  identify  goods  and  services 
financed  from  loan  proceeds,  expenditures  incurred,  and  the  use  of  local  funds  under  project 
components. The  BSRDC  has  a well-established PPP  cell  with  nine  full-time  staff.  ADB TA  to 
provide hands-on training to the BSRDC on PPP is ongoing (footnote 5). Currently, the BSRDC 
has three PPP projects under implementation and four under processing. 
 
22. 
Procurement. Goods and works will be procured in accordance with ADB Procurement 
Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). The civil works contracts will be undertaken in 
four  contract  packages,  which  are  estimated  at  more  than  $29  million  and  will  be  procured 
through international competitive bidding, using ADB standard bidding documents for large civil 
works contracts with post-qualification under the single-stage, two-envelope system. Consulting 
services will be procured in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, 
as  amended  from  time  to  time).  The  BSRDC  will  select  two  international  consulting  firms  to 
supervise the construction of civil works under the project using ADB procedures for quality- and 
cost-based selection, full technical proposals, and a quality–cost ratio of 80:20. One consulting 
firm  will  be  engaged  for  the  Muzaffarpur  region  and  the  other  for  the  Samastipur  region.  The 
terms  of  reference  for  consulting  services  and  a  procurement  plan  indicating  thresholds  and 
review  procedures,  goods,  works,  and  consulting  services  are  in  the  project  administration 
manual.

D. 

Poverty and Social 

24. 
Poverty reduction and social impact. A poverty and social assessment survey of 604 
households was conducted, and 40 focus group discussions were held in 53 villages in project-
influenced  areas.  Most  respondents  stated  that  the  project  will  provide  communities  with 
enhanced access and mobility. In the short term, the project will generate an estimated 412,200 
person-days  of  employment.  Improved  links  to  markets  and  production  centers  will  create 
additional  economic  and  employment  opportunities.  Improved  connectivity  will  help  rural 
residents transport their products more quickly and obtain higher profit margins, as they will no 
longer  depend  solely  on  local  markets  and  middlemen.  An  estimated  4,524,182  people  will 
experience the economic benefits brought about by the project.16  
 
Gender  and  development. Most women in the project area are homemakers, as rural 
25. 
women  rarely  work  outside  the  home  unless  they  are  very  poor.  During  in-depth  gender 
assessment  of  the  four  roads—interviewing  381  women  and  holding  31  women-specific  focus 
group  discussions—women  indicated  that  improved  road  conditions  would  provide  better 
access  to  health-care  services,  higher  levels  of  education,  economic  opportunities,  and  social 
interaction.  Shorter  travel  times  will  leave  more  time  for  productive  activities,  health  care,  and 
self-development.   
 
A gender action plan has been prepared to (i) promote women’s participation in project 
26. 
planning,  design,  and  implementation;  (ii)  maximize  women’s  access  to  project  benefits; 
(iii) provide  opportunities  to  increase  women’s  skills,  income,  and  participation  in  decision-
making;  and  (iv)  minimize  social  vulnerability.  Findings  from  meaningful  consultations  with 
women  guided  the  incorporation  of  practical  and  implementable  gender  mainstreaming 
activities,  including  (i)  involving  women  in  community-based  afforestation  programs;  (ii) 
employing women in construction; and (iii) ensuring the sustainability of road safety awareness 
efforts in roadside communities by having road safety specialists train women in project-affected 
areas,  who  will  provide  training  in  turn  to  their  communities.  In  addition,  BSRDC  staff  will 
undergo training to improve gender-sensitive designs and measures in future road projects.   
 
27. 
Provisions  in  the  bidding  documents  for  the  civil  works  contractors  (i)  ensure  that  all 
applicable  labor  laws  are  complied  with,  including  the  prohibition  against  employ  children  in 
construction; (ii) encourage the employment of the poor, particularly women; and (iii) ensure that 
wages for men and women are equal for work of equal value. To ensure that all gender issues 
are  addressed,  a  gender  specialist  will  be  engaged  under  the  construction  supervision 
consultant to implement the gender action plan. A gender focal officer in the BSRDC will ensure 
the implementation of the gender action plan.17 
 
28. 
HIV/AIDS.  As  per  statistics  from  India's  National  AIDS  Control  Organization  for 
December 2010, the rate of new cases of HIV has been reduced by 50% since 2000. Bihar is

population.  State,  district,  and  block  campaigns  are  undertaken  by  the  health  department  and 
the Bihar AIDS Control Society to raise awareness. Based on public consultations, the project 
has incorporated measures to mitigate HIV/AIDS risks by having nongovernment organizations

To  combat  risks  of  human  trafficking,  the  Government  of  Bihar  launched  in  2007  a 
29. 
program  to  prevent  the  trafficking  of  women  and  children  and  to  ensure  comprehensive 
rehabilitation  for  victims.  In  addition,  Action  against  Trafficking  and  Sexual  Exploitation  of 
Children,  an  international  nongovernment  organization,  implements  awareness-building  and 
prevention programs in the state.  
 
E. 

Safeguards 

Land acquisition and resettlement. The project is categorized as Category A for land 
30. 
acquisition  and  resettlement.  The  project  was  developed  with  a  commitment  to  minimize  land 
acquisition through appropriate technical design. Road widening will occur mostly within existing 
rights-of-way,  and  bypasses  are  used  in  congested  areas.  A  100%  census  was  conducted 
based  on  detailed  design.  Four  resettlement  plans  were  prepared  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) and the policies and regulations of the governments of India 
and Bihar.  
 
Project land acquisition will affect 118 hectares consisting of 6,516 land plots and 3,937 
31. 
structures: 3,674 private, 7 community, 131 religious, and 125 government. Of the 3,674 private 
structures,  3,106  belong  to  titleholders  and  568  to  non-titleholders.  Of  the  9,523  displaced 
households, 2,660 are physically displaced and 6,863 economically displaced. The entitlement 
matrix  provides  for  specific  compensation  and  resettlement  assistance  for  the  types  of  losses 
caused  by  the  project.  Compensation  for  lost  assets  will  be  paid  on  the  basis  of  replacement 
cost. Resettlement assistance for lost income and livelihoods will be provided to titleholders and 
non-titleholders  alike,  with  special  measures  available  to  vulnerable  displaced  households. 
Resettlement plans have been approved and disclosed on the ADB and BSRDC websites. The 
existing  Environment,  Social  Development,  and  Resettlement  Cell  of  the  BSRDC,  which  was 
instrumental in the effective implementation of the resettlement plans for ongoing loans, will also 
implement this project. The total cost of resettlement is estimated at $33 million. 
 
32. 
Indigenous  peoples.  The project is categorized as Category C for indigenous people. 
Seventeen  households  belonging  to  scheduled  tribes  are  present  in  the  project-affected  area 
along State Highway 83. During project preparation, consultation with all 17 households found 
that  they  did  not  have  collective  attachment  to  the  project  area  or  live  together  in  distinctive 
communities. The study did not show any difference in impact between indigenous groups and 
others.  The  social  impact  assessment  confirmed  that  the  socioeconomic  impact  of  the  project 
will not differ for tribal groups and the larger population. Special provisions have been made in 
the  resettlement  plans  to  address  impacts  on  indigenous  people.  If  any  significant  impacts  on 
indigenous people are identified, an indigenous peoples plan will be prepared and submitted to 
ADB for approval. 
 
Environment.  The  project  is  categorized  as  Category  B  for  environment.  Initial 
33. 
environmental  examinations  (IEEs)  were  prepared for  the four  roads. The findings  of  the IEEs 
indicate that the project is unlikely to cause any significant adverse environmental impacts, as 

8 

 

 all  four  roads  already  existed  and  no  forest  area,  wildlife  sanctuaries,  national  parks,  critical 
habitats, or similar eco-sensitive areas are traversed. Most of the impacts are likely to be during 
construction and associated with earthmoving, ground shaping, heavy equipment operation, and 
travel over unpaved roads. These impacts are temporary, and mitigation is readily designed and 
easily  implemented.  The  environmental  management  plan  will  be  implemented  mainly  by  the 
contractors during construction and by the BSRDC during operation. The existing Environment, 
Social  Development  and  Resettlement  Cell  will  monitor  implementation.  All  IEEs  have  been 
disclosed in compliance to ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). 
 
34. 
Addressing the challenges of climate change. Portions of state highways in northern 
Bihar  are  susceptible  to  floodwaters  originating  in  the  Himalayas. 18  Northern  Bihar  has 
experienced  worsening  flooding  since  the  1980s,  highlighting  the  need  for  more  stringent 
countermeasures to ensure project objectives are sustained. The BRSDC has adopted in road 
improvement design the following key features: (i) upgraded road surfaces constructed at least 
1 meter  higher  than  the high flood  level  with  50-year  return period,  (ii) stratified  and multistory 
roadside plantation where timber wood and similar erosion-stopping varieties are planted on the 
right-of-way  periphery  to  break  flood  flow  velocity  and  protect  the  road  embankment,  (iii)  the 
installation of larger cross-drainage, (iv) the construction of new side drains particularly in built-
up areas, and (v) stone pitching and bioengineering along strategic areas where breaches and 
inundation have previously occurred.  
 
35. 
Greenhouse  gas  emission  mitigation  and  monitoring.  To  partly  offset  greenhouse 
gas emissions from increased traffic arising from road upgrading, the BSRDC has committed to 
implementing  1:10  compensatory  plantation19 for  all  trees,  regardless  of  ownership,  following 
the  Tirhut 20  Social  Forest  Model.  This  model  has  strong  community  participation  and 
performance-based  agreements  to  ensure  that  at  least  80%  of  the  trees  survive.  The  BSRDC 
will  monitor,  in  coordination  with  the  State  Pollution  Control  Board  and  the  Transport 
Department,  roadside  tailpipe  emissions  and  ambient  air  quality  to  keep  track  of  greenhouse 
gas  emissions  and  air  quality.  Finally,  to  reduce  reliance  on  fossil  fuels,  all  contractors  will  be 
encouraged to install solar panels to power all lighting at campsites, with appropriate provision 
made in the bidding documents.
